Overview

Course Description

This course is an introduction to programming in Java. Topics include fundamentals of Java programming, including object-oriented programming, primitive data types, control structures, methods, objects, classes, class inheritance, simple graphical user interface and event-driven programs using Swing. Oject-oriented design using the Unified Modeling Language will also be introduced.

This course is an excellent course both in terms of work force relevance and continuing education. Java is widely used in industry and is syntactically very similar to many other popular languages such as C#, JavaScript and Ruby. Java is also widely used in educational settings and if you intend to earn a higher degree, this course may transfer to cover the introductory object oriented programming course common at many other institutions.

Course Goals

The following goals will be addressed in the course:

  • Explain the role of the bytecode compiler
  • Compare and contrast if and switch statements
  • Use loops for repetitive tasks
  • Program using built-in Java objects, including Collections
  • Describe the basic Java packages
  • Create programming code using a class that includes objects, methods, and constructors
  • Use class variables, instance variables, and local variables in the same application
  • Explain the difference between instance and class methods
  • Explain the difference between interfaces and abstract classes
  • Create programming code using a class that uses command-line parameters
  • Create an application using simple Swing components and layout managers
  • Write event handlers for common graphical objects
  • Explain the benefits of multitasking

Grading

Please refer to the course syllabus for more information.

Late Work

Weekly assignments are expected to be completed on-time. It is important that you practice what you learn on a weekly basis in order to keep up with the material. To support this and to allow discussion of assignments in-class, this work is not accepted. However, I do understand that life happens, and your lowest weekly assignment score will be dropped to account for this.

Project assignment are longer duration assignments and it is expected that you will manage the time to allow life to happen while still completing the work on time. As these are smaller in number and thus each one a larger part of your grade, these assignments have a small late window where they may still be submitted for reduced credit. However each calendar day the project is late will drop the score earned by 10%. Thus, you may want to carefully consider whether it is better to turn in what you have on time or take the extra time to complete the work for reduced credit.

Grade Breakdown

Class Attendance & Participation 15%
Weekly Assignments 30%
Project Assignments 30%
Exams 30%

Office Hours

To get one-on-one assistance with coursework, it is strongly recommended that you contact me to arrange a specific time to meet. If you just drop by, you may find I am working with someone else or that there is not enough time available to address your concerns. During high-traffic periods, for example right before an assignment is due, I may need to limit my time to 10-15 minutes per student, in order to allow time for everyone.
